items.message: River levels remain high but are currently stable on the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook. Flooding is expected to affect locations near these watercourses, with low lying land expected to be most affected. Flooding is possible at the road at Reybridge during today, Friday (08/12/2023) and over the weekend. Further rainfall, sometimes heavy, is forecast throughout Saturday (09/12/2023). River levels are expected to rise in response, peaking on Saturday afternoon. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue or update this alert and issue warnings if necessary. We are monitoring defences and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 09/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

The River Lavant is high and rising, following a wet autumn and 20mm of rain Saturday. From 09:30 09/12/2023 minor flooding could affect fields, rural roads and gardens, including small parts of Sheepwash Lane, Pook Lane and the Green in East Lavant. At The Sadlers in Westhampnett, the river will be near the top of the bank, and close to properties. River flooding should not affect Chichester City Centre. Rain should clear from 12:00 09/12/2023. The River Lavant should peak by 19:00 09/12/2023, about 15cm higher than it was on Thursday 07/12/2023. Isolated showers on Sunday and Monday could cause small river rises, but flood risk is not expected to increase again until Tuesday 12/12/2023 when another 20mm of rain is possible. The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We are operating the River Lavant Flood Alleviation Scheme to reduce the flood risk. We will update this message by 22:00 09/12/2023.

The Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes are high and rising, following 10mm of rain Saturday. Flood water will continue to affect land and caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre, parts of the car park at Tescos on Shripney Road, as well as fields near Shripney Lane. In Barnham, only small amounts of water are expected to affect fields and roads. Rain should clear by 11:00 Saturday 09/12/2023, and only isolated showers are forecast Sunday and Monday. The Aldingbourne Rife through Bersted could continue to rise until 07:00 10/12/2023, but only rise by 15cm. Flood water will continue to affect caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre, and might approach properties on Durban Road. Water levels will remain sensitive to any additional rainfall next week. Currently rain is predicted on Tuesday 12/12/2023. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barnham, if you have them. We are clearing grilles through Barnham, and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 22:00 09/12/2023.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Saturday 9th December and for the next few days. Water levels continue to remain high in this area. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Sunday 10th December, or as the situation changes.

The water level in the Eastern Yar is high and continues to rise following the heavy rainfall (20mm) recorded yesterday (07/12/23). Today (Friday 08/12/23) and tomorrow (Saturday 09/12/23) the river will continue to flood low lying land, access and cycle tracks, gardens and roads throughout the Yar valley. Today, the weather should remain fairly dry and at Alverstone, from 13:00 onwards, the water level should begin to fall. At Sandown it will rise for much of the day. From the early hours of Saturday morning (09/12/23) further heavy rain is forecast, with up to 20mm expected. If this rain affects the river, then it is possible that some property flooding will occur. We have operated Bembridge sluice. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please ensure that any products used to protect gardens and property from flooding can operate over the next 24-36 hours.  This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Saturday 09/12/23.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to rainfall over the past few weeks and remain high at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming weeks. 

The groundwater level at Draycot Foliat is higher than normal for this time of year and is currently very slowly rising.  The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and groundwater levels and may start to rise again if there is further rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding.  Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 15/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 8.92 m and is steady. The drain level is 8.55 m and is rising slowly. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.30 m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86 m, and the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93 m. 

Further rain, heavy at times, is forecast overnight tonight and into Saturday morning. We expect river levels to respond to this and flooding remains possible over the next few days. 

We are currently unable to pump at Huish Episcopi pumping station due to the high river level. items.description: Creyke, Mill and Broadlane Becks at Cottingham

items.message: Groundwater in Hambledon is high. Since Tuesday 05/12/2023, the level at our borehole at Whitedale Farm has fallen by 64cm. In the last 48 hours, 22mm of rain has been recorded at Worlds End. On Saturday 09/12/2023, another 15-25mm of rain will affect East Hampshire. From Sunday 10/12/2023 to Tuesday 12/12/2023, showery rain is forecast. In the next couple of days, groundwater levels are expected to continue rising again. Water levels in cellars will become deeper, and it is possible that more properties on West Street will experience cellar flooding by the end of next week. Long range forecasting is difficult, but there is currently an indication that more settled weather is possible from Wednesday 13/12/2023 until Sunday 17/12/2023. Groundwater levels in Hambledon are expected to continue rising into the week beginning 18/12/2023. We are liaising with the Hambledon Flood Action Group. Please remove any valuables from cellars, and if you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Thursday 14/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: Groundwater levels in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle have remained high for the last 7 days and the Idsworth Lavant is flowing throughout all villages. Today (07/12/2023), heavy rain is forecast in Hampshire with 15 to 40mm possible. On Saturday 09/12/2023, up to 25mm of rain is possible. Groundwater levels are now expected to rise throughout the next week and flow in the Idsworth Lavant will increase. Pumps which prevent water from entering property will be required for a small number of properties. During heavier rain events, surface water could flood property. If heavy rainfall continues affecting the area in December, the Chalton Lavant could begin to flow in the next couple of weeks, causing deep road flooding and further property impacts. We are liaising with the Flood Action Group. If you use pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Thursday 14/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the recent rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole in Longacre in the Lambourn Valley. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected within the next few days by flooding from groundwater.

The groundwater level at Longacre is higher than normal for this time of year but is currently very slowly declining. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and groundwater levels and may start to rise again if there is further rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 15/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have fallen overnight but are forecast to rise again at the Leek river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall this morning, 09/12/23. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. The water level in the Lukely Brook is high and rising. In the last 7 hours, 16mm of rain has been recorded at Carisbrooke. This is a modest amount but follows weeks of prolonged wet weather. Currently, the river will be close to bankfull in most locations and could come out of bank from Old Westminster Lane to Towngate Bridge flooding riverside footpaths. With the river level high, surface water will flood the bottom of Castle Street. Heavy showers will affect the area until 12:00 (Saturday 09/12/23). The river should peak by 13:30, but will remain very high until lunchtime today. Property flooding is not currently expected. Our operational contractors are making sure the river is kept free of reported blockages. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please avoid flooded riverside footpaths. This Flood Alert will be removed by 17:00 on Saturday 09/12/2023.

The water level in the Monktonmead Brook at St John's Station is high and rising. In the last 7 hours 15mm of rain has been recorded in Ryde. This is a modest amount but follows weeks of wet weather which is making the river much more responsive than normal. From 11:00 this morning (09/12/23) a small amount of water will impact the railway tracks, upstream of St Johns Station. Flooding of the station buildings or property is not currently expected. Rain, which will be heavy at times, will continue this morning but should clear the area by 12:00. The rest of the Saturday should remain dry. The river should peak by 13:00 but will remain high for several hours before it finally begins to fall. Our operational staff are keeping the Monktonmead Brook clear of blockages. We continue to monitor the forecast. This Flood Alert will be removed by 19:00 on Saturday 09/12/23.

items.message:
This Flood Warning has now been removed. Please note that a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low-lying land is still possible. No property flooding is expected today.

Catchments are now saturated, and rivers will be responsive to further rain. Showers are forecast on Friday, followed by a band of heavier rain overnight and into Saturday. This overnight rain will be heavy at times and is likely to cause rivers to rise again.

River levels have fallen but remain responsive to further rainfall. The current rainfall is expected continue throughout this morning, 09/12/2023, with another band coming across Sunday morning. Areas most at risk are around Alconbury Brook at Hamerton, The Alconburys, Little Stukeley and Brampton. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don’t put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will update this message by 6pm today, 09/12/2023.

The water level in the River Blackwater at Ower and Cadnam River remains very high following heavy rainfall (20mm) yesterday, but it is now slowly falling. Throughout Friday (08/12/23) the river will continue to flood low lying land and roads, and it will be very high around the mill at Wellow. Today, the weather should remain fairly dry and the water level should continue to slowly fall. From the early hours of Saturday morning (09/12/23) further heavy rain is forecast, with up to 20mm expected. If this rain affects the river, then it is possible that some property flooding will occur. We continue to monitor the forecast. Our operations staff will work to ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure that pumps used to protect property can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Saturday 09/12/23.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.51 m and fairly steady at the time of writing. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.

The drain level at Currymoor is 6.37 m and rising (up to 10mm/hour). For up-to-date water levels visit the gauge section of our website (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/station/3064)

A band of further heavy rain is forecast early on 09 December. Therefore, flooding remains possible over the next few days.

We continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels closely and our staff are checking flood defences and pumps.

We are pumping, including at Stanmoor, Northmoor and Saltmoor stations, and Currymoor when river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is also being used to evacuate water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence.

Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Do not attempt to drive, walk or cycle through flood water.

This message will be updated by midday on 09 December.

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but steady on the River Windrush. Therefore, the risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Newbridge area.  The weather forecast is for further rain this morning which should clear this afternoon. It should be dry overnight but further rain is forecast for Sunday morning.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. The Western Rother is rising in Liss, following 10mm of rain Saturday. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens and rural roads in Fittleworth will continue. A river response similar to Thursday is expected between Liss and Midhurst, with only very minimal flood impacts in those communities. From 17:00 09/12/2023 flood water could approach isolated properties at Lodsbridge near Selham and Fittleworth. Near Selham and Fittleworth, river levels on Saturday could rise a little higher than they were on Thursday. Rain should clear by 12:00 Saturday 09/12/2023, and only isolated showers are forecast Sunday and Monday. The river should begin to fall by 04:00 10/12/2023 near Selham and 17:00 10/12/2023 in Fittleworth. Another 10-20mm of rain is forecast Tuesday 12/12/2023, which could see flood risk return. Water levels will remain sensitive to additional rainfall over the next few weeks. Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 09/12/2023.

The rain has eased and river levels are now reducing.

Flooding for Christchurch Harbour and the tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon is possible for the morning tide at 09.31 on Saturday morning 09/12/23.  A low pressure weather system will cause sea levels to be higher than forecast in the tide tables.  Sea spray overtopping along the coast is possible and high water levels in the harbour are forecast.  A level of 1.28 mAOD is expected with Force 6 West South Westerley wind.  Flooding to roads and low lying land is possible and conditions can apply one to two hours either side of high tide. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff will be closing flood gates if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  This message will be updated by 11.00 AM on 09/12/23, or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.51 m and fairly steady at the time of writing. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.
The drain level at Currymoor is 6.37 m and rising (up to 10mm/hour). For up-to-date water levels visit the gauge section of our website (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/station/3064)
A band of further heavy rain is forecast early on 09 December. Therefore, flooding remains possible over the next few days.
We continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels closely and our staff are checking flood defences and pumps.
We are pumping, including at Stanmoor, Northmoor and Saltmoor stations, and Currymoor when river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is also being used to evacuate water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence.
Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Do not attempt to drive, walk or cycle through flood water.
This message will be updated by midday on 09 December.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: October and November 2023 have been exceptionally wet. Groundwater is high, within a metre of the surface at East Dean, and rising 10cm each day. 15-30mm of rain is forecast Thursday afternoon 07/12/2023. From 09/12/2023 minor groundwater flood impacts are possible, with springs appearing, water flowing on roads, water in basements or under floorboards, and affecting the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean. A further 20mm of rain is possible Saturday 09/12/2023. Only small amounts of rain are currently forecast Friday, Sunday and next week. Groundwater is expected to continue rising until 15/12/2023 at Chilgrove and until the New Year at East Dean. If the second half of December is dry, groundwater flood impacts might ease in January. However, groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 13/12/2023.

The water level in the Lymington River at Brockenhurst remains very high but is now slowly falling. In Lymington, the water level is rising, with high tide at 07:30 and 19:45 compounding the river’s ability to drain to sea. Land, drainage ditches, roads, watersplashes and gardens through the New Forest will remain flooded throughout the course of Friday (08/12/23). Today the weather remains fairly dry and the water level will continue to fall. From the early hours of Saturday morning (09/12/23), further heavy rain is forecast with up to 20mm expected. Flood impacts will continue throughout the weekend, with property flooding at heightened risk. We are monitoring the situation very closely. The river is flowing rapidly and watersplashes will be deep. Please do not drive through floodwater and ensure you can take action to protect property over the next 36 hours. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Saturday 09/12/23.

The water level in the Danes Stream remains high, following heavy rainfall (35mm) yesterday (Thursday 07/12/23). Milford Dam has operated correctly to reduce the amount of water flowing to Milford on Sea. However, the water level in the village will remain high throughout the course of today (Friday 08/12/23) and some footpath flooding and garden flooding is likely to affect Milford on Sea High Street. High tide at Lymington is forecast at 07:30 and 19:45 and this will also act to reduce the river’s ability to drain to sea. Today, the weather remains dry. From midnight on Saturday (09/12/23) further heavy rain is forecast with up to 20mm expected. If this impacts the river, then water levels will remain consistently high until Sunday (10/12/23). We continue to monitor the forecast. Please keep away from riverside footpaths in Milford on Sea, especially at Milford Bridge opposite Lucerne Road. If footpaths are flooded it will be difficult to see where the edge of the main river channel is. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Saturday 09/12/2023.

River levels are rising at the Ebbesbourne Wake river gauge on the River Ebble.  This is as a result of the overnight rainfall and falling on catchments that are already saturated.  Flooding of low-lying land, roads and farmland is possible. There is a possibility of flooding on the River Ebble and tributaries.   Further rainfall is falling and we are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, consider installing property flood resilience equipment, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 11.00 AM 10/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Piddle from Alton Pancras to Wareham
items.message:
River levels are remaining high on the River Piddle.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast overnight which will cause river levels to rise again.
Flooding is affecting Alton Pancras, Piddletrenthide, Piddlehinton, Druce, Puddletown, Athelhampton, Affpuddle, Briantspuddle, Throop and Wareham including Purbeck View Park today on 08/12/2023.
Further rainfall is forecast overnight.
River levels are remaining high.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 09/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors, low lying properties around Muchelney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.92m and is stable. The drain level is 8.55m and rising slowly. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3m, the road from Muchelney to Long load above 7.86m and the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35m. 

We are currently unable to pump at Huish Episcopi pumping station due to the high river level, but will commence as soon as river levels allow. Further rain, heavy at times, is forecast overnight tonight and into Saturday morning. River levels and saturated catchments will be responsive to this, and flooding is expected to continue over the next few days. 

The River Yeo at Muchelney is forecast to remain high throughout this unsettled period. The situation is being continually monitored and staff are checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on local road closures. This message will be updated by 3pm on 09/12/2023 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high on the Lower River Nidd due to recent heavy rainfall.  The areas most at risk include land around the lower River Nidd and its tributaries including Sand Beck, Sike Beck, Pool Beck and Great Gutter. Levels have peaked and are expected to continue falling. However, further rainfall is forecast over the weekend and we expect further rises. We continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying land and footpaths near local watercourses. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 02:00PM on 09/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent at Carlton on Trent including Beck Cottage
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Torksey river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue. Areas most at risk are Carlton on Trent including Beck Cottage.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 72 hours. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.
Please move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety and have a bag ready with vital items like medicines and insurance documents.
This message will be updated by 13:00 today, 09/12/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent at Newark Tolney Lane and Riverside Marinas
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Farndon river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are Tolney Lane Caravan Site and riverside marinas in Newark.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 72 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until Monday.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area and liaising with emergency services.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and activate your flood plan.
This message will be updated by 13:00 today, 09/12/2023 or as the situation changes.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Friday 8th December 2023. River levels are expected to continue to rise, but we are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for continued unsettled weather over the next couple of days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Saturday 9th December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: Groundwater levels at the Kingston Russell and Dickley Down boreholes have risen very rapidly overnight. It is likely that some roads will be flooded in the South Winterbourne, Hooke, Sydling and Cerne Valleys. Householders with pumps and other property level resilience measures should deploy them now. Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can damage adjacent property and may put your own and emergency responders lives at risk. This message will be updated tomorrow, Saturday the 9th December

items.description: The River Bure, Spixworth Beck and surrounding Becks
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely from today, Friday 8th December, until tomorrow evening, Saturday 9th December. We are currently seeing higher river levels than normal in the area of Spixworth. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for continued unsettled weather over the next couple of days, with further rainfall forecast for Saturday morning. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message tomorrow morning, Saturday 9th December.

items.description: River Ouse at York - St George's Field and Queen's Staith
items.message:
River levels are high on the River Ouse at York in response to recent heavy rainfall. The river level in York at the Viking recorder have peaked at 3.6m, and are forecast to fall during Saturday. Further rain is expected today and tomorrow and levels are expected to rise again. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Properties along Queen's Staith, on South Esplanade, Friars Terrace and Tower Place. St George's Field carpark and Rowntree Park.  

Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and put your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. We continue to monitor the forecast. 

This message will be updated by 9pm Saturday 09/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high on the River Ouse at York  and Naburn in response to recent heavy rainfall.  Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Naburn Lock Buildings and Lock Cottages.  

Levels in York at the Viking recorder are currently around 3.6m, and are forecast to fall on Saturday.  Levels at Naburn Lock are just over 2.96m. Further rain is expected on Saturday and Sunday and levels are expected to rise again. 

Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and put your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. We continue to monitor the forecast.  

This message will be updated by 9pm Saturday 09/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is forecast to affect low lying land near Skeffling and Winestead Drain. Further rainfall is expected over the weekend which is expected to keep river levels high. 

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and pumping in the wider area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  

This message will be updated by 7:00pm Saturday 09/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Roding, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Hillmans Cottages; Ongar Road; Roding Road; Roding Lane today, Saturday 9th December and tomorrow. 

Further heavy rainfall is forecast throughout today which will cause river levels to rise further.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

This message will be updated by 5pm on Saturday 9th December, or as the situation changes.

Groundwater levels at the Dickley Down borehole have risen very steeply. Some property flooding as well as disruption to the road and sewer networks is expected. Home owners with property level resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers should check that they are in place and working properly. Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave from vehicles can damage adjacent properties. Stay out of flood water which is hazardous to you and emergency service staff who may have to rescue you. This message will be updated tomorrow, Saturday the 9th December.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Barle, River Exe, River Lyn, River Mole, River Bray

items.message:
Flooding is possible overnight Friday (8th December) and through Saturday (9th December).
Catchments remain saturated after the recent rainfall and another band of rain will fall overnight tonight and into tomorrow causing rivers to rise. 
The main areas of concern are Lynton, Lynmouth, Challacombe, Meethe, South Molton, Dulverton, Brushford, Winsford, Exton and Exford. River levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers. 
Possible flood warnings may be required. 
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated on Saturday or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Barnstaple, Braunton, Ilfracombe and Combe Martin area
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Caen, Bradiford Water, River Yeo

items.message:
Flooding is possible overnight Friday (8th December) and through Saturday (9th December). 

Catchments remain saturated after the recent rainfall and another band of rain will fall overnight tonight and into tomorrow causing rivers to rise. 

The main areas of concern are Barnstaple, Braunton, Ilfracombe and Combe Martin.  River levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  

We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated Saturday or sooner if the situation changes.

The River Ems is high and rising, following a wet autumn and 15mm of rain Saturday. From 09:00 09/12/2023 minor flooding could affect small areas of fields, rural roads and gardens of properties on North Street, River Street and at the Wren Centre, Westbourne as well as near Lumley Mill, Victoria Terrace and Brook Meadows, Emsworth. Rain should clear from 12:00 09/12/2023. The River Ems is expected to rise 20cm in total and should peak by 15:00 09/12/2023, at a similar level as it was on Thursday 07/12/2023. Isolated showers on Sunday and Monday could cause small river rises, but flood risk is not expected to increase again until Tuesday 12/12/2023 when another 20mm of rain is possible. The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Westbourne and Emsworth, if you have them. We are operating our structure at Constant Springs and clearing grilles to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 22:00 09/12/2023.

The water level in the Upper River Meon is high and rising. In the last 5 hours, 15mm of rain has been recorded at Warnford. This is a modest amount but follows weeks of prolonged wet weather. From 09:00 this morning (Saturday 09/12/23) surface water flooding will impact some roads through West Meon, possibly at Shoe Lane, Church Lane and at Bucks Head Hill, Meonstoke. From 11:30, at Wickham, the river may flood gardens and the Millennium Water Meadows. Rain, which will be heavy at times, will continue this morning but should clear the area by 12:00. The rest of the Saturday should remain dry. At Wickham the river is unlikely to peak until 13:30 this afternoon. Property flooding is not currently expected. We continue to monitor the forecast and will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. This Flood Alert will be removed by 11:00 on Sunday 10/12/23.

items.description: Pearl Brook at Horwich, area close to the river from Church Street to the M61
items.message:
River levels are rising on the Pearl Brook.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Pearl Brook.
Flooding is affecting Horwich town centre from Bridge Street and Old Station Park to the M61, homes and businesses on Winter Hey Lane, Mason Street and adjoining roads including St. John Street, New Brunswick Street, Emmett Street, Taylor Street and Chorley New Road from 09:00 AM on 09/12/2023.
We are clearing debris from weed screens in the area.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your surroundings.

River levels are rising on the River Douglas.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Douglas, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around The River Douglas from Horwich Star Vale to Appley Bridge including Adlington, Blackrod, Wigan, Standish, and Gathurst.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the day.
We are clearing debris from weed screens in the area.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: Upper River Colne and Radlett Brook
items.message:
River levels are rising on the Radlett Brook, Colne, and Mimmshall Brook due to heavy rainfall this morning, Saturday 9th December. 

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Radlett Brook, Colne, and Mimmshall Brook, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Waterside, Lowbell Lane, London Colney, and Warrengate Road. Further rainfall is forecast throughout today and river levels will continue to remain high. 

We will continue to monitor the forecast and deploy teams to clear any blockages in the river as necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated by 5pm on the 9th December, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Heavy rain has fallen over North London and Hertfordshire today, Saturday 9th December. River levels are rising in the Waltham Forest, Waltham Abbey, Waltham Cross, Barnet, Nazeing, Enfield, Chingford, Edmonton, Cheshunt and Tottenham areas. 

Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible this afternoon and evening. Flooding from surface water could also occur. 

Further heavy rain is possible this afternoon but tomorrow, Sunday 10th October and Monday are forecast to be drier. 

We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. We are constantly monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages. 

We will update this message by 5pm today or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels are falling on the Woodridings Stream and River Pinn today, Saturday 9th December. A Flood Alert is in force for the area and further rainfall is forecast throughout today. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible. 

Further rainfall is forecast today but tomorrow, Sunday 10th December and Monday are forecast to be drier. Where flooding has occurred, there may be standing water remaining for several days. 

We will continue to monitor river levels closely and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated by 5pm today, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Piddle Valley
items.message: Groundwater Levels at the Doles Ash borehole have risen steeply following several days intense rainfall. Homeowners with property level resilience measures, such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers should put them in place and check that they are working correctly. Do not drive through flood water as the bow wave can seriously damage adjacent properties. Food water is dangerous - entering it can put your life and that of emergency responders at risk. We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this message tomorrow, Sunday the 10th December. In an emergency contact Dorset Council on 01305 221000.
